title: Where did the phrase “with flying colors” come from and why is it so popular? - Quora
tags: Etymology of English Phrases (Origin or History of English Phrases)

response.answer_text: “Colors” are the flag of any military unit - land or sea. “Flying colors” implies a victory has been won by that unit, as defeat could mean the “colors” fell into the hands of the enemy. Capturing the flag of an enemy was a “big deal”. Displaying the victor’s flag was similarly a “big deal” as at Iwo Jima. Why Civil War Flags Were So Important Being a color bearer was considered a mark of great distinction and it required a soldier of extraordinary bravery. The job was to carry the flag where the regimental officers directed, while unarmed and under fire. Most importantly, color bearers had to face the enemy and never break and run in retreat, or the entire regiment might follow. Conversely, to capture the battle flag of an opponent was considered a great triumph, and captured flags were cherished as trophies. Accounts of Civil War battles in newspapers at the time would generally mention if any enemy flags had been captured. “Flying Colors” were extremely important then and still today we placed an American Flag on the Moon.

With due respect to the online etymological resources, the earliest uses of the expression with flying colors are not in fact nautical, and they go back much further than 1706. The best way to determine the origin of a phrase is to examine its earliest appearances in the record. Our phrase appears at least as early as 1612: “philips army with flying colours sent lately into ireland vpon gift made vnto him by the pope, etc.” And from 1625: “they levied and brought into the field many men, vnder flying colours, their colours.” Thus the expression with flying colors comes from a military usage, referring to an army marching with its standards and banners waving. As to when the phrase adopted its current sense, I cannot say.

To pass with flying colours means to pass with distinction. This term has a nautical history. It derives from when ships would return home with their "colours" (another word for flags) flying to show they had been victorious. https://www.grammar-monster.com/sayings_proverbs/pass_with_flying_colours.htm

Flying colors (1706) probably is from the image of a naval vessel with the national flag bravely displayed. Flying machineis from 1736 as a theoretical device. Flying saucer first attested 1947, though the image of saucers for unidentified flying objects is from at least 1880s. Origin and meaning of flying by Online Etymology Dictionary
